title: 107_hr1623
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines "historically women's public college or university" as a higher education institution established in the US between 1836 and 1908 for women's industrial education. "Historic building or structure" refers to a building listed on the National Register of Historic Places or designated as a National Historic Landmark. The term "historic building or structure" refers to a building listed on the National Register of Historic Places, designated as a National Historic Landmark, or located within a designated historic district. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Preservation and restoration grants are available for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. The Secretary awards grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings using funds from the National Historic Preservation Act for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Grants come with specific conditions. Grants awarded to women's public colleges or universities for preserving historic buildings come with conditions such as no alterations without Secretary's approval and providing public access to the property. Grants for preserving historic buildings require the grantee to agree to no alterations without Secretary's approval and to allow public access for interpretive and educational purposes. The grantee must agree to allow public access for interpretive and educational purposes when receiving funds for a building listed on the National Register of Historic Places. For grants related to historic buildings or structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places, National Historic Landmarks, or designated historic districts, the grantee must provide 50% of the program costs from non-Federal sources, with the Secretary funding the remaining 50%. In-kind contributions such as property or personnel services from non-Federal interests can also be used for the program. Funding provisions state that up to $16,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006 may be available under the grant program, with non-Federal contributions allowed through in-kind contributions of property or personnel services. Funding provisions allow up to $16,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2006 for the grant program, with non-Federal contributions permitted. $2,000,000 for grants in 2002 allocated to Mississippi University for Women. For fiscal year 2002, $2,000,000 is allocated for grants under subsection (a) to specific universities including Mississippi University for Women, Georgia College and State University, University of North Carolina, and Winthrop University. For fiscal year 2002, $2,000,000 is allocated for grants to specific universities including Mississippi University for Women, Georgia College and State University, University of North Carolina, Winthrop University, University of Montevallo, Texas Woman's University, and University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma. For fiscal year 2002, if less than $16,000,000 is available, the amount allocated to each listed institution, including University of Montevallo, Texas Woman's University, and University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma, will be reduced. For fiscal year 2002, if less than $16,000,000 is available, the amount allocated to each listed institution will be reduced. Funds for fiscal years 2003-2006 will be distributed according to specific provisions. Allocations for fiscal years 2003-2006 will be distributed by the Secretary to eligible grantees on a uniform basis. The Secretary will create necessary regulations to implement this Act.
